Situation1: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: I sat at the front of the classroom, my notes spread out, ready to guide my mentees through the final steps before their big project deadline. They looked at me expectantly, eager for the knowledge and experience I promised to share. I had spent hours preparing this session, determined to give them every tool they needed to succeed. Just as I was about to begin, my phone buzzed. It was a message from the legislative aide I’d been trying to reach for weeks—she had ten minutes to talk, right now, about the bill I’d been fighting for. My heart pounded. As an activist, I knew how rare and crucial this opportunity was; missing it could mean losing momentum for the policy change I believed in. But as a mentor, I saw the anxious faces before me, counting on my guidance. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my full attention at the same moment. My mind raced, caught between the urgent call for advocacy and the immediate needs of those I was meant to support.
